title: AI and Deep Learning in Medicine
content: Artificial intelligences and deep learning is currently impacting medicine and could transform the healthcare industry not only in terms of the technological advancements, but also in restoring the patient-doctor relationship for better patient outcomes and experiences.

title: Resistance to Technological Change in Healthcare
content: The US medical field’s resistance to technological change and learning from other healthcare models.

title: Role of AI in Medicine
content: How AI and deep learning is currently impacting medicine, and the future possibilities.

title: Gut Microbiome and Health
content: Gut microbiome—Its role in health, impact on glycemic response and fuel partitioning, and how deep learning could improve our research and treatment.

title: Combination of AI and Human Doctors
content: Why machines combined with human doctors is superior to one without the other.

content: How AI and machines can reinstate medicine as an attractive career (and alleviate physician burnout).

content: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Pros and Cons of GLP-1 Weight Loss Drugs and Metformin
content: Discussion on the pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

content: Discussion on the longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength.

content: Discussion on fasting and weighing the risk vs. reward.

title: Heart Attack Risk from Vioxx
content: There was no data to support that, and it seemed like a very odd explanation for this excess of heart attack. We went over the data, and I said, ‘You know what, we’ve got to publish this because this is really important.’ And so we put together a paper and went to JAMA. It was published. There were other small studies, withheld by Merck, that showed excess heart attacks in those taking Vioxx. One in 50 absolute risk for hard mortality outcome. At the time, it was not clear who was at risk, but 80 million people took Vioxx. Most people that have severe osteoarthritis are also having comorbidities that would put them at risk for heart attack (a ubiquitous disease).

title: AI and Deep Learning in Medicine
content: Recognizing AI technology. What we’re talking about now is a specific subtype of AI, which got its birth just over 10 years ago, called deep learning, neural networks that allow for inputs. And they could be millions, billions of data points. It could be images, it could be speech, could be text. And then it goes these layers of artificial neurons, which are not very much like neurons. But nonetheless, they can distinguish features progressively as they go through this network. And then you get outputs. Technological advancements made in the field have been recognized by the A.M. Turing Award: Geoffrey Hinton and his colleagues received the award for engineering breakthroughs of deep neural network computing. Ongoing studies will demonstrate superiority of image definition accuracy, or as good as through machine.

title: Deep Learning Innovation and the Atrial Fibrillation Case Example
content: Sources of deep learning development. Eric believes deep learning innovation will come from outside of big pharma. Google, Microsoft, Amazon all recognize this as the greatest opportunity for growth and also a noble mission of improving health. Startups, some governments like in China, the UK and other places are taking interest and investing in this space. The FDA has selectively approved algorithms for reading various types of scans, but such algorithms are widespread in China, for example. Consumer-approved AI. Apple Watch algorithm for atrial fibrillation. A lot of people have an Apple Watch who are young and have zero risk of atrial fibrillation and they get a cardiogram and it gets them anxious and they may even get workups by a cardiologist. This is a problem where we have marketing of an algorithm, the first deep learning algorithm in medicine.

title: Gut Microbiome and AI
content: CGM discussion: Peter on how AI could impact continuous glucose monitoring: If there’s anything that’s ripe for AI, it would also be CGM coupled with other data. In other words, I don’t think the CGM data as the input feed would be sufficient. You’d have to constantly be pairing it with your activity and other sensors. If you had the cortisol sensor and the lactate sensor, then that starts to become remarkable predictive power. Peter’s dream with the CGM: This is my pipe dream is I want to be able to say, Go into the algorithm and tell it your desired average glucose, your desired variability. I want an average glucose that’s below a hundred milligrams per deciliter or below 110 milligrams per deciliter. I want a standard deviation that doesn’t exceed 15 milligrams per deciliter. Now you tell me what I can eat. Spend the first month watching me eat, learning how my body responds to every different food and go from there.

title: AI and the Gut Microbiome
content: Gut health is a significant area of interest. There is skepticism about how gut microbiome can change patient health. DNA of the microbiome is stable from day to day, so analysis would remain relevant for a period of time. A study demonstrates a devised a machine-learning algorithm integrates blood parameters, dietary habits, anthropometrics, physical activity, and gut microbiota to accurately predicts personalized glycemic response to real-life meals. However, there are challenges in microbiome research such as changes in bacteria species sequence is just as important as the density of the type of bacteria and sequencing species and evaluating density is expensive to do correctly.

title: Developments in Microbiome Research
content: There are interesting developments in microbiome research. For example, shotgun sequencing of bacteria (true metagenomics) is used to sequence each species of every organism that’s found. The genome sequence is equally as important as the type of bacteria. However, there is still no clear understanding of how to manipulate the gut microbiome.

title: Role of Gut in Glycemic Response to Foods
content: There are varying views on the gut’s impact on glycemic response to foods. Some studies suggest that even identical twins respond differently to food due to variation in the gut microbiome. However, there are questions about whether the gut microbiome really adds anything above other factors like glycogen stores and insulin sensitivity of the muscle.

title: AI and Human Doctors
content: Machines combined with human doctors is superior to one without the other. Machines can vastly improve areas like radiology and critical care. However, humans will always be better at the interaction with other humans and the connection/bond. Machines don’t have the context and deep, human nuanced issues that doctors can pick up.

title: AI and Physician Burnout
content: Physician burnout is an issue and is at its peak. Physicians have become data clerks and they’re squeezed for time, and they can’t care for people when they don’t have time. Machines can help give doctor’s their time back.

title: AI Implications for Doctors and Patients
content: AI has implications for both doctors and patients. Patients will be empowered with their own data so there will be less requirement for doctor-led diagnoses of the most common conditions. The medical specialities will shift away from a common-treatment focus.

title: AI Multimodal Collection
content: Optimizing deep-learning solutions in healthcare will require collaboration between the United States and China. The experiment would be to develop a planetary digital infrastructure with all the data of each individual and continually assess and assimilate processed inputs: federated AI. The genome will never be fully deterministic; it can be probabilistic but is hampered by inadequate numbers.
